Description: A forepart fragment of a hollow terracotta horse, modelled in the round, the neck and head remaining, with details of harness in relief, both linear with dangling horse-brass suspenders, and rows of conjoined ring-and-dot patterns. A suspension-hole is pierced through the neck. The ears are damaged; the right eye flaked away. Two-piece mould. Yellow-buff Aswan kaolinite ware, with a grey core, and covered with a buff-grey slip. Painted lines, showing the eyes and mane, and more of the harness, in black fired-on ceramic colour.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Elephantine. Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD. Comparanda: Near: Adams 2000: 93, fig. 31d, pl. 20d:4, and ibid.: 93, fig. 31h, pl. 20d:8 (Nile silt, no moulded decoration), both from Meinarti in Nubia, from domestic contexts between about late fifth and mid-seventh century AD; Bakry 1968: pl. lxxv, fig. 25(a) and pl. lxxvi (after p. 53), from a Coptic cemetery near Esna; Boutantin 2004: 9, fig. 5, dated fifth to sixth century AD; Roeder 1959: pl. 39l, from Hermopolis Magna; Weber 1914: no. 444, said to be from Elephantine.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3759)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
